reviewText:
You can't make a bad movie about the life of Pablo Escobar...that is impossible.  Say what you want about him, but he was the Al Capone of Colombia, perhaps even more legendary than Capone himself.  I have seen Cocaine Cowboys (2006), The Two Escobars (2010), Blow (2000) with Johnny Depp, and the True Story of Killing Pablo (TV movie 2002), all dealing with the life and death of Pablo Escobar.  Escobar Paradise Lost (2014) is not a biographical film on Pablo, but rather a romance/thriller on a certain episode in the life of Pablo.  The story of the film begins in the early 1980's with a group of Canadian hippies that settle a remote beach-front in Colombia (the film was originally shot in Panama).  Among them is an idealistic young man by the name of Nick (Josh Hutcherson) who makes living from giving surf-lessons.  Fate has it one day he runs into a beautiful girl who is helping the local community with the money given by her uncle, Pablo Escobar (Benicio Del Toro)...the notorious drug lord whose name went down in history as one of the most controversial figures of Colombian political and social scene since the creation of its modern day country.

Benicio Del Toro's portrayal of Pablo Escobar truly stands out from all the rest. Del Toro holds a monopoly on playing historically controversial Latin personalities, beginning with Ernesto Che Guevara and ending on Pablo Escobar.  Who knows, in the future he might play others: such as Simon Bolivar, Rafael Trujillo, or maybe even Fidel Castro.

I thoroughly enjoyed this film, despite the fact that it concentrates of what seems to be a limited period of the life of Pablo Escobar, a few years before the time where he constituted himself prisoner in 1991 and put an end to his assassination campaign in exchange for a lenient treatment and sentence, and a promise that he would not be extradited to the United States.

The story is that of a young Canadian surfer (Josh Hutcherson) established on a beach in Columbia who falls in love with the niece of Pablo Escobar (Benicio Del Toro) without knowing so. He gets increasingly dragged into Escobars hyper violent and ruthless universe and is increasingly reluctant to become part of it, hence the films title: Paradise Lost.

I will, of course, not mention the plot or how it ends but will just mention that this is a dark, rather despairing and hyper violent thriller. More than the violence itself, it is the tension and the almost suffocating atmosphere that comes across which makes this film so worthwhile. Most of this is due to the fantastic performance of Benicio Del Toro who manages to make to make his character into someone that is simply terrifying and utterly ruthless, as the real drug lord probably was.

Also well presented in the scenario are a number of features associated with the reign of the drug baron.

One of these was the carefully cultivated image of a Latin American Robin Hood that he created for himself and behind which he tended to hide. It may even have been sincere, given his own modest origins, but it was also very convenient and very useful for him to play the protector and the defender of the poor and destitute. It seems to have largely worked since, at least in his own region, he seems to have been very popular, had tens of thousands of supporters and was even elected in the early 80s as a member of the Columbian House of Representatives.

Another feature, linked to some extent to the previous one, was the collusion that existed between him, the local police and even some of the armed forces whose services he had bought after eliminating those (allegedly hundreds) that disagreed.

However, because the whole film revolves around the personality of Pablo Escobar and the fantastic performance of Benicio, the main events of his career, while mentioned, tend to take a backseat. For instance, the film never shows explicitly to what extent he managed to control the cocaine traffic towards the United States. At one point, it is estimated that 80% of what reached the US was sent by him or his associates.

Another limit is that the film contains virtually nothing about his relations with other Colombian drug lords at the beginning of his career, and nothing at all about his constant and merciless war of assassinations against his rivals of the Cali cartel. A third weakness is that the effort deployed the Reagan and Clinton administrations to combat drugs, the huge financial and military support provided to the Columbian government and the just as important constant pressure put on it to combat both the left-wing guerrillas and the drug lords are either barely mentioned and entirely omitted.

Essentially, the whole film is about the personality of Pablo and Benicios very powerful incarnation of the drug lord, with the benevolent mask and pretence slipping at times and then disappearing completely to be replaced by the merciless monster lurking beneath it. This is both the main strength of this superb film, but also perhaps also its main limitation. Four stars, with at least two for Benicios performance

I lived in Colombia back in the 1980s when Escobar was king.  The people loved him but also feared him.  When there was a natural disaster or people in a town lost their jobs because a factory moved, etc - Escobar was right there handing out money.  He also gave people jobs and always gave them housing with it - so they were indebted to him.  If they thought about trying to find another job, they would also have to find another home.  Not easy in that country, especially not for the typical working class Colombian.  This movie was entertaining and I especially like the character of Marie, who was like most of the young educate Colombian women I knew when I lived there - very aware of the handicaps of their country being under the thumb of the drug lords, but also doing everything they could to educate and help the bulk of the people.  Del Toro did a marvelous job capturing Escobar's personality - he was a lot of fun and charming but at the same time ruthless and shrewd.  Colombia is a very beautiful country, with its beautiful beaches, mountains, and flatlands, varied topography, but I can't imagine anyone thinking "paradise" when they see it.  The poverty is obvious everywhere, rural and urban areas.

I enjoyed this film very much, but this is a work of fiction, not a historically accurate documentary.  That said, Del Toro perfectly captured Escobar's twisted "morality", his charm, and skillful manipulating of media, political systems and financial institutions.  The "I've done some stuff I wish I didn't have to, but it's not my fault and I always had a good reason for doing what I did" BS criminals use to justify their actions. As though providing free clinics and building churches cleaned the blood off his drug money.  The problem is, there's nothing you can do to scrub money that dirty clean.  Contaminated drug profits destroy everything it touches, a lesson Nick (Josh Hutcherson) learns too late. Some reviewers have criticized Hutcherson's performance and I would take issue with that.  I thought Hutcherson perfectly captured Nick's naivete, his difficulty understanding the culture and language and his desperation to get himself, his lovely fiance (Escobar's niece) and his brother's family out of Columbia.  From his awkward first meeting with Maria, to the even more awkward marriage proposal surrounded by cameras and reporters as Escobar used the occasion to boost his image, to the slow realization actually who and what Maria's uncle really was, to his utter confusion as he tries to extract himself from a situation he can barely comprehend, I felt his journey was completely believable.  The supporting cast was great, with the possible exception of Claudia Traisac as Maria.  I'm not a drama critic, but it seemed she was in over her head in this film.  She was good, but could have been better.  The cinematography and locations were lovely.  It was also nice to see a film that didn't fall back on the old standbys to sell a story; the unrealistic happy ending and the obligatory sex scene.  I heartily recommend this film.

Watch this fine film, then "Sicario" (2015) and you will be shocked at the CIA cozying up to Escobar's Medelln cartel in a fight to weaken the 'less controllable' Mexican cartels.  Crazy stuff ... and also check out the extraordinary film, "Kill the Messenger" (DVD only on N'flix, but if you have HBO on Demand, it's there, too).  Call these three flicks an immersion in cocaine, without the crash and bloody nose.  Thanks for reading!

Cliff Curtis' portrayal of Escobar in Blow lasted about one minute onscreen and I felt like I had actually met the infamous El Padrone. Benicio Del Toro's Escobar was lifeless and sullen like Marlon Brando in Apocalypse Now. He would have made an excellent Saddam Hussein, however. Even if you're just looking for some trashy violent action, the film disappoints viewers because it only alludes to and doesn't show Escobar's revenge on a local gang of thugs who deserved it. local community is in fact one of the biggest drug-barons of his day, credited with supplying up to 80% of the Cocaine
that found it's way from 'Columbia' into the U.S.
How he portrays himself hides a very ruthless and calculating criminal...
After meeting 'Nick' who he calls 'Nico' now accepted as his nieces boyfriend, 'Pablo'offers a job on the estate along with
luxury accommodation, which 'Nick' accepts.

'Pablo's' business dealings, he wants 'Maria' to leave with him....it doesn't happen.
Eventually the authorities will close in on 'Pablo's' empire leaving the drug-baron with the one option, to make a deal and
give himself up, however before surrender takes place he must hide his fortune to protect his family's future, he has singled
out several locations for this and charges several trusted allies to follow his instructions to hide the fortune, 'Nick' is one
of those chosen.......however, 'Pablo' has no intention of leaving any witnesses to the wheabouts of his vast fortune which
will leave 'Nick' in a fight for survival.
This is actually a well-crafted film with a strong story-line, though not being award-worthy it is well worth taking time-out to
watch.

I'm a huge Benicio del Torro fan, which is why I was excited to see him play Pablo Escobar in this flick. Josh Hutcherson plays the prototypical idealistic/stupid foreigner (gringo) who along with others of his kind decides that drug capital Columbia is the perfect place to set up a surfer camp & storefront food/drink business. Hmmmm if that doesn't already ring a bell, then you're one of the folks that probably gave this movie a high rating. But of course, not long thereafter these group of idealistic white kids start getting harassed by local thugs, which also coincide with Josh's character meeting Maria who just happens to be Pablo Escobar's niece. The courtship phase & character development of the young lovers is omitted from the movie, which means that the audience doesn't get invested in their love, or them for that matter, as the story progresses. Huge problem right there, as the movie isn't over for another 1.5 hours and we don't care enough about the main characters who movie is centered on. If Josh's character was completely in the dark about the dangers of his new "home" and terror that locals deal w/ on a daily basis, he gets a quick lesson as he goes into a store to try on a blazer (to look formal to meet Maria's family, thus Escobar, for the first time) as the local thugs burst into the store to show him who/how things are run in those parts by releasing a seemingly rabid dog on him. Message received?!

While del Torro is charismatic & holds this weak movie together, the fact that the bond between him and his nephew-in-law is so poorly developed in the story-telling means that the trust that a person like Escobar would need to allow/embrace this foreigner as a new member of his close-knit family is pretty much ridiculous. I mean, are we really supposed to believe that a man like Escobar would allow his beloved niece to marry a gringo who's not of any socio-economic/political importance but just a random white guy from Canada that's a drifter/lost idealistic type? Even so, if you don't have the stomach to be a tough guy or someone useful in the drug operation then why again would Escobar trust you? While Escobar shows him some kindness by killing the local thugs who released the dog on him, Josh's character is somehow inept or oblivious to the realities of how violence is central to Escobar's lifestyle nor his own complicity to things happening around him. This is important because as the film progresses the moral dilemma's that Josh's character ends up having becomes comically absurd, because what else but being engulfed in violence could come from "falling in love" with the niece of a druglord and entering their inner circle?

The weak plot & poor storytelling are the primary reasons why I hated this boy-meets-girl-but-girl-is-related-to-a-dangerous-druglord flick. A Romeo and Juliet-like love story entwined in a (stereotypical) Colombian theme, filmed in Panama, with Mexican actors (and accents) posing as Colombian thugs... okay... Could have been worse I guess... but this could have been much more.

While Del Toro's, and Hutcherson's performances were great, and kept the weak plot afloat, the story itself lacked quite a bit of detail and depth to make it seem a bit more believable. The relationship between Maria (Traisac) and Nick (Hutcherson) happened magically overnight (quite unrealistically I might add), making the plot feel very forced, and somewhat absurd in a lot occasions. Some of the thugs had super noticeable Mexican Spanish accents, and there was very little depth to some of the secondary characters that, while brought to life by good acting, ultimately felt short due to the thin plot. Come on, a 15 year old Martin with a wife and kid? Even in Colombia, that's a bit too young!

All in all, it's a good movie, with great acting, and beautifully directed and set, but in the end you're left feeling a bit cheated and unsatisfied by this  directorial debut from Andrea Di Stefano.

As "Escobar: Paradise Lost" (2014 release from France and Spain; 120 min.) opens, we are told it is "Medellin, Colombia, June, 1991". We see Escobar making a phone call to his old mother, informing her he is going to prison tomorrow. On this last night of freedom, Escobar gathers his closest aides, including Nick, and everyone is assigned a particular task to hide the economic wealth of the cartel. Escobar tells Nick that he needs to kill his guide after the loot has been hidden, much to Nick's horror. We then go back "A Few Years Earlier", where we see Nick, a Canadian surfer, and his brother Dylan building a surf camp. Nick meets Maria, a beautiful local girl, whom we later learn is related to Escobar (he is Maria's uncle). At this point we're 15 min. into the movie. Will Nick kill the guide? What becomes of Nick and Maria? To tell you more would spoil your viewing experience, you'll just have to see for yourself how it all plays out.

Couple of comments: first, the movie's main events surrounding Escobar are based on facts, including the historical surrender in 1991. But I have my doubts that the parallel story lines involving Nick and Maria really happened. If they had, we probably would have been told at the beginning that this movie was "based on true events" or something like it. Not that this diminishes the enjoyment of the film, as somehow this mix of facts and fiction works great. The relationship between Nick and Maria is fun to watch, in particular as Claudia Traisac (playing Maria) is nothing short of a glowing presence on the big screen, what a delight! Benicio del Toro, portraying Escobar, is a heavy-weight and overpowers everyone, similar to what Marlon Brando did in The Godfather. Josh Hutcherson is okay as Nick. His best moment in the movie is when he and Maria attend a birthday party for Escobar, and along the way Nick comes to the realization of what is really going on and what Escobar does. Priceless! The last 30 min. of the movie provide a nice pay-off and will have you on the edge of your seat.

"Escobar: Paradise Lost" showed up without any pre-release fanfare or hype at my local art-house theater here in Cincinnati last weekend, and I finally had a chance to check it out. The matinee screening where I saw this at was attended okay but not great. I must say that I was very pleasantly surprised by this movie, which turned out to be much better than what I had expected. If you are in the mood for a tough-as-nails crime drama with several top-notch performances, I encourage you to seek this out, be it in the theater, on Amazon Instant Video or eventually on DVD/Blu-ray. STRONGLY RECOMMEDED!

No guy likes to meet his girl's parents. Period. Okay, there may be a few exceptions but those guys are probably crazy. We all get that fear in the back of our mind that her father, or older brother, will give us the "if you hurt her" threat/promise to do something awful to us in retaliation. Now imagine that the girl's most dominant male family figure is murderous drug lord Pablo Escobar. How do you think meeting her family would go then? It might go something like it does in Escobar: Paradise Lost, a film about Pablo Escobar that tragically isn't really about Escobar at all even though it really needed to be.

The reason is that the other characters in the film are a total bore, and that includes The Hunger Games star Josh Hutcherson as Nick, a Canadian living the surf life in Colombia. The movie is really about him, and how he gradually enters Escobar's dangerous world simply by falling in love with the man's niece, Maria, played by the lovely Claudia Traisic. Nick is in the country along with his brother (Brady Corbet) and sister-in-law, thinking they've found a little corner of paradise. When Nick meets Maria it's love at first sight, and unfortunately we don't get to really see much of the courtship or much of their relationship at all. Actor-turned-director Andrea Di Stefano seems to be on fast forward getting to an inevitable conflict between Nick and Escobar, so that we never get to see what led up to it. In fact, the story begins by flashing ahead to 1991 on the day Escobar is to turn himself into authorities after a bloody and brutal conflict. He's just asked Nick to do something terrible; hiding Escobar's money in a secluded area then killing anybody who assists him in the task. Can he do it? Will he do it? How the heck does someone like Nick end up in this predicament? Of course it's ridiculous, which may be why Di Stefano doesn't spend too much time on the details.

Jumping back a few years, we're breezed through Nick's meeting with Maria's family, which comes off like a fish-out-of-water comedy with Escobar at its center. We see the vicious kingpin as both a national hero and the family clown; walking around in sweat shorts and Boston Celtics caps, playing in the pool with his kids and basically acting like the most benevolent crime boss ever. Del Toro, who specializes in characters who are slightly out of left field, is masterful in the role because he's not trying to be flashy about it. He's simply captivating and the best reason to see this movie which is pretty average the rest of the way. Hutcherson is solid but Nick has little personality to speak of.  He's not a complete dummy (not yet, anyway), and begins to suspect there's more to Escobar's empire than it seems. When he asks Maria how Escobar made his money she innocently replies "Cocaine", before rationalizing why that's perfectly okay.

This would have been a better story if it focused more on Escobar and his tenuous relationship with Nick, an unlikely member of the family if there ever was one. Think of how tense some of the scenes could have gotten as Escobar, who loves Maria dearly, continued to treat Nick with kindness until some later act forces his dark side to emerge. But we don't get that. Instead, Di Stefano has the situation turn on a dime with no explanation at all, simply to get to the final chapter action sequence. Admittedly, Di Stefano does a great job with it, and so does Hutcherson as the simple kid waaaay out of his depth. As he's chased across the countryside by Escobar's goons, Hutcherson is believably terrified, occasionally flashing a look that screams "How did it come to this?!!?"  Shot in Panama, the scenery is gorgeous all around, and Di Stefano knows how to stage an effectively gripping set piece. He's got a bright future as a director, and clearly knew to give Del Toro the freedom to embody Escobar in his own way. But it's hard not to think how much better this movie would have been if Escobar was the true focus. Escobar: Paradise Lost isn't the biopic on the drug lord people have been hoping for, but it's a decent enough thriller that will probably be remembered for teasing how amazing a true Escobar film could be with Del Toro.
